description.narrative: The Tanzania Corruption Tracker System (CTS) is an electronic system whose purpose is to keep track record of publicly available information on corruption in Tanzania. the CTS works to increase information knowledge transparency accountability and responsi veness in the fight against corruption. Some of the tasks of the CTS include: building a data bank on cases and information about corruption. Other tasks include establishing and maintaining an electronic quick archive that can be accessed to read and moni tor cases on corruption establishing a mechanism that can be used as an instrument to assist the state institutions to gauge their performance and take action in response against corruption behaviours.The purpose of CTS IV is to scale up recording dissemin ation of publicly available information on cases of corruption. The CTS IV will engage more and use the mainstream media as a strategy of forming knowledge amongst citizens and mounting insurmountable pressure of government agencies and public leaders to a ct against corruption. The goals objectives and expected results of CTS IV build on the cumulative goals and objectives and expected results developed since 2009.The broad objectives of CTS IV are: corruption is documented widely discussed criminalized by citizens politicians and state agencies 2012, public and parliamentary pressure is mounted on state agencies to take action against corruption by end of 2012, state agencies and government are infuluenced to respond to public pressure against corruption a nd media is actively engaged to report document and form citizens opinion against corruption. Specific objectives include:an expanded data bank of information, an established electronic bilingual website, an established maintained mechanism that can be use d as an instrument to compel state institutions to take action, an established interface and network between the tracker and religious leaders as agents of change.Expected outputs are: at least 800 000 online readers and viewers are reached by end of 2012, at least 200 analytical articles are uploaded on the CTS site and 80 articles stored in the archive by end of 2012,at least 20 000 corruption briefs are printed, at least TV and Radio spots on corruption are aired, at least one media review reports on med ia coverage of corruption are documented and published by end of 2012.
